instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  - Voltage on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> fluctuating but <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is stable.
threads.message: This board had corrosion mainly around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. If I plug into the top USB-C port the board will get 20V and turn on normally. If I plug into the bottom port the voltage on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> fluctuates from 0V up 5V and right back down. So F3001 goes up and down. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> also goes up and down from 0V to 3.4V. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> also goes up and down. I've replaced everything that looked bad. I can't find any shorts. I'm guessing I might be to the point of having to replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. But also wondering if I should, or can, just leave it alone and not use the bottom USB-C port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  - Voltage on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> fluctuating but <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is stable.
threads.message:
Check resistance to ground on all LDO outputs of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
Do all these voltages try to appear?
Compare with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  - Voltage on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> fluctuating but <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is stable.
threads.message: Just making sure you've tried a new USBC Port? They are connected I'm pretty sure, and I know if one of the ports is bad, it will cause this. If you have, likely an issue near <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> if not the chip

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  - Voltage on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> fluctuating but <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is stable.
threads.message: Ok, so I pulled the new <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> capacitor I put on because this wasn't happening with the old burnt out one and I wanted to see if that might help. I was measuring around 3KOhms to ground. Without <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> on at all the board turned on. And yes, all the voltages were coming up and down including the LDO voltage. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> again and the board is working. My replacement <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> must have been damaged in the soldering process. It's a little messy because I was avoiding using hot air to attach the new one so it might have gotten burnt out internally. Thanks for the tips.
